data.title: One-win wonders â€” every F1 driver with a single GP victory to their name
data.meta_description: For most F1 drivers, winning a grand prix is a fantasy that's never fulfilled. For others, their first victory is the gateway to further glory. And then there are those who experience the top step of the podium just once in their careers: these are the drivers with just one grand prix win
data.text:
In Formula 1â€˜s 73-year-long history, 115 drivers have stood on the top step of the podium. Many have gone on to win multiple grands prix and even championships but not all have been so successful. Bested by their team-mates, shackled by lacklustre machinery, affected by life-threatening injuries and sometimes simply not good enough, they have never been able to repeat their greatest day in racing.

Excluding one-off Indy 500 winners (the race was included in the championship from 1950-â€™60), the list of F1â€™s single-time grand prix winners currently runs to 27 drivers â€” their number increased thanks to Lando Norris and Oscar Piastriâ€˜s first wins, but reduced by George Russellâ€˜s second F1 victory.

Here are grand prix racingâ€™s one-hit wonders, starting with the most recent. Click on a name to jump to the entry or scroll down to read each one.

Drivers who have won only one F1 grand prix

â€¢ 2024: Oscar Piastri â€¢ 2021: Esteban Ocon â€¢ 2024: Lando Norris â€¢ 2012: Pastor Maldonado â€¢ 2020: Pierre Gasly â€¢ 2008: Heikki Kovalainen â€¢ 2008: Robert Kubica â€¢ 1996: Olivier Panis â€¢ 2004: Jarno Trulli â€¢ 1989 Alessandro Nannini â€¢ 1995: Jean Alesi â€¢ 1975 Vittorio Brambilla â€¢ 1977: Gunnar Nilsson â€¢ 1975: Carlos Pace â€¢ 1975 Jochen Mass â€¢ 1971: Francois Cevert â€¢ 1972: Jean-Pierre Beltoise â€¢ 1966: Ludivico Scarfiotti â€¢ 1971: Peter Gethin â€¢ 1964: Lorenzo Bandini â€¢ 1965 Richie Ginther â€¢ 1961: Giancarlo Baghetti â€¢ 1961: Innes Ireland â€¢ 1956: Luigi Musso â€¢ 1959: Jo Bonnier â€¢ 1951: Luigi Fagioli â€¢ 1952: Piero Taruffi

Oscar Piastri

2024 Hungarian Grand Prix

Itâ€™s unlikely that Oscar Piastri will spend much time on this list, given his career so far and the performance of the McLaren he races in F1. Long tipped as a future race-winner, the former Alpine junior driver landed a full-time race seat in F1 after a contract tussle between Alpine â€” which had neglected to secure his services â€” and McLaren.

He was competitive against team-mate Lando Norris in his rookie season, and can blame bad luck for not winning in the first half of 2024. But he finally seized his chance at the 13th round in Hungary. Having qualified alongside Norris on the front row, he passed the sister McLaren on the inside of Turn 1 at the start, and looked on course for victory.

But, the team pitted Norris early, to fend off the slight risk of being overtaken by Lewis Hamilton, and this left him ahead of Piastri once the Australian had made his stop. McLaren told a clearly reluctant Norris to return the place, and there were several laps of tension before he did move over, allowing Piastri to take a debut F1 win at the Hungarian Grand Prix.

Read more

Lando Norris

2024 Miami Grand Prix

After numerous heartbreaking defeats, luck finally swung Lando Norrisâ€™s way in Miami. The horizon had looked bleak for those following in the wheeltracks of Red Bull and Max Verstappen in 2024, off the back of a dominant 2023 season, but McLaren and Norris had the measure of the world champions in Miami.

His charge to the front from fifth on the grid, helped by the addition of a well-timed safety car on lap 30, paid back the previous bad luck heâ€™d had in 2021 at Monza â€” where he missed out to team-mate Daniel Ricciardo â€” and Sochi â€” where late rainfall forced him to fall down the order with a handful of laps to go.

Once ahead of Verstappen in Miami, Norrisâ€™s pace continued to impress, meeting the chequered flag seven seconds clear of the trailing field â€” securing a long-overdue win in the process.

Read more

Esteban Ocon

2021 Hungarian Grand Prix

The Hungaroring brought a shock result in 2021, triggered by treacherous conditions at the start, during which Valtteri Bottas misjudged his braking and caused a big collision heading into Turn 1 on the opening lap.

This put himself, Sergio Perez and two others out of the race while, also caught up in the mayhem, Verstappen was forced to compete with a heavily damaged car. Conditions then dried up rapidly but Mercedes misjudged this and kept Hamilton on the intermediate tyres while everybody else went to slicks under the red flag.

The Mercedes driver then had no option but to pit after a lap of racing and he rejoined at the back of the pack while Ocon took lead. Sebastian Vettel was in second but the Alpine driver had enough pace to hold him off. The only driver with the pace to challenge for first was Hamilton, but he had an almighty task ahead.

Cutting through the field rapidly, he reached Oconâ€™s team-mate at which progress stalled. In a monumental defence, Fernando Alonso kept the seven-time world champion behind him in fifth for 12 laps. By the time Hamilton eventually muscled through, it was too late: he couldnâ€™t make it up to Ocon in time, and the Frenchman clinched the first victory for the Enstone team since Kimi RÃ¤ikkÃ¶nenâ€˜s 2013 Australian Grand Prix win.

Read more

Pierre Gasly

2020 Italian Grand Prix

Pierre Gaslyâ€™s tale is a story of redemption. Following an impressive rookie season in 2019, he was rewarded with a big move to Red Bull. That stint, however, ended after just 12 races and he was demoted back to Toro Rosso. This here though he rediscovered his mojo and was standing on the podium in Brazil before the season end.

The following season, amid a global pandemic, Gasly was able to go one better with a fantastic victory in Monza after many of the front-runners had a race to forget. Verstappen, Charles Leclerc and Vettel all retired, while Lewis Hamilton fell foul to a team error.

It was Gaslyâ€™s chance to shine. On lap 19, Kevin Magnussenâ€˜s Haas came to a halt, causing a safety car. Luckily for Gasly heâ€™d already pitted the lap before, having been pulled in by his AlphaTauri team while mired in the midfield.

Due to Magnussen stopping close to the pit entry, the pitlane was closed the moment the safety car was deployed so marshals could retrieve his stricken Haas â€“ but Hamilton and Mercedes jumped the gun coming in straight away when no cars were permitted to do so.

As a result the then-reigning champion was given a penalty, as the pitlane re-opened and most others piled in.

This bumped Gasly up to third behind Hamilton and Lance Stroll. When the race restarted, Leclerc crashed heavily at Parabolica and the race was now stopped.

At the standing restart, Gasly got the better of Stroll and slotted into second, with only Hamilton ahead. When the Mercedes man pulled into the pits to serve his penalty, Gasly took the lead and fended off a surging Carlos Sainz to take a famous debut win by 0.4sec.

Read more

Pastor Maldonado

2012 Spanish Grand Prix
